Award.AwardTitle: Undergraduate Studies with Environmentally Oriented Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The University of North Dakota is using environmental awareness to recruit and retain academically talented and financial-needy students to major in biology, chemistry, mathematics or environmental geography. The teaching of environmental science "in context" is being employed to provide engaging and meaningful learning experiences as students progress toward degree attainment and career goals. To achieve the recruitment objectives, 16 students, in two cohorts, are being awarded scholarships with priority given to American Indian students. To help ensure the retention and progress of these students, the scholarship program also places a premium on intensive advising and student engagement activities, of which participation in an environmental issues seminar series is most prominent. This scholarship program enables students from underrepresented groups with limited financial opportunities to enter STEM programs. The University of North Dakota has a history of successful work with American Indian students by providing a strong support system; however, these students have minimal involvement in non-medically related majors. Therefore, this project is taking an important step that is increasing awareness about opportunities in STEM majors and engaging these American Indian students as majors in traditional STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of North Dakota (UND) Arts and Sciences (A&S) S-STEM NSF award was received in 2011 (DUE-1060183), totaling $598,110, with the scholarship portion comprising $520,000 of the overall award. This award enabled the creation of a program named Undergraduate Scholarships with Mathematics and Science Training in Environmental Research (US MASTER I). The goal of this program was to provide 16 scholarships targeting 1st generation and underrepresented minority (URM) students. Over 20 faculty members from Chemistry, Biology, Mathematics, and Geography created and participated in this program.

From 2011-2017, nearly 50 students participated in the US MASTER I program (Table 1), far exceeding the proposed reach of the program. Twenty-six (54%) were from rural settings, twenty-six (not the same) were 1st generation students, as result of collaboration with UND TRIO. This indicates that we were able to reach a diverse array of individuals specifically addressing needs in a rural setting. Initially, we recruited freshman; to date, eight (17%) students graduated from UND, and six of these are pursuing graduate degrees in STEM. Two of our students are recipients of prestigious graduate research fellowship awards.

The program aided by UND services, while at the same time contributing to the institution’s evaluation and implementation of new educational, advising and recruiting strategies. The demonstrated effectiveness of the 1st year seminar resulted in the permanent implementation of a similar seminar into the required Chemistry curriculum. One essential and highly valued outcome (based on external assessment) has been success with the close mentoring and advising of students. One-on-one mentoring and daily interaction were critical for student retention, especially among underrepresented minority students. It appeared that students advised by more caring faculty were more likely to stay in the program.

The main feature enabling the professional development of students and providing close relationships was an ongoing seminar course. The seminar featured numerous activities promoting research and teaching experiences. Based on the students’ feedback, we have experimented with several different seminar formats. The latest reviews suggest that most students’ appreciated was a “mixed mode” seminar with joint meetings for all students, as well as break-out sessions that targeted students at varying stages of degree progress (e.g., 1st year students vs. research-oriented students). The joint session approach also involved a newly implemented “a non-fiction book club format” that involved popular science books. These book discussions often included important socioeconomic and environmental issues students and faculty could connect to.

Another essential element of the US MASTER program was encouragement for students to participate in original research. Later, we expanded this focus to allow students to participate in peer-teaching through involvement with a a tutoring program, providing teaching experience.   Similarly, as reported in literature, we also felt that active participation in research increased student interest in science. This was facilitated through the seminar and advising, and systematically highlighting these opportunities for students. Our efforts resulted in 18 (46%) students participating in various forms of research experiences, and were partially enabled by providing financial support for research supplies. The participation in research enabled students to build better portfolio for the future career goals as well as a close understanding the particular discipline.  We have also found that the tutoring experiences provided our students with teaching experience, which has been shown to have a similar impact as research training on student retention in STEM.

Our students made impressive contributions to their mentors’ research programs. One of our student participated in a drone interdisciplinary research between chemistry and aviation. Another work resulted in a co-authored publication titled “County level incidence rates of chronic lymphocytic leukemia are associated with residential radon levels” in the journal Future Oncology.

Perhaps the most rewarding outcome of this work is the success of our students as they leave UND for future careers. One of members of the first USMASTER cohort, is currently MS student in the Dept. of Biology at UND, and furthermore  was awarded the prestigious graduate fellowship from NSF to support her work in prairie restoration. Another student received the Arthur J. Schmitt Leadership award, which supports her doctoral work in the Integrated Biomedical Sciences Program at the University of Notre Dame. From later cohorts, one student was a finalist for the Goldwater Award, and is a MS student in the Global Health Program at the University of Notre Dame. We anticipate that other participants will have similar levels of success once they graduate from UND.
